title: Is it necessary to graduate from MIT or another 'high level' institution if you'd like to be an astronaut or work at NASA? - Quora

response.answer_text: No.  One of the really nice things about NASA is that they realize that which school you attended doesn't mean a damn.  As long as the school's program is accredited, no one cares what school you went to. In the current astronaut corps, 96 different universities are represented: U.S. Air Force Academy	8U.S. Military Academy at West Point	8Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT)	7Stanford University	7U.S. Naval Academy	7Georgia Institute of Technology	5University of Washington	5University of Houston - Clear Lake	4University of Texas at Austin	4Embry-Riddle Aeronautical University	3Purdue University	3University of California - San Diego	3University of Maryland	3University of Tennessee	3Air Force Institute of Technology	2Florida Institute of Technology	2George Washington University	2Ohio State University	2Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute	2Rice University	2University of Alabama	2University of Arizona	2University of California - Los Angeles	2University of Houston	2University of New Hampshire	2University of Notre Dame	2University of Virginia	2Air University	1Albion College	1Brown University	1California Institute of Technology	1California Polytechnic State University	1City College of New York	1Colorado State University	1Columbia University and London Business School	1CSU Fullerton	1Davidson College	1Drexel University	1Flight Test Engineering Air University	1Frostburg State University	1Harvard Business School	1Harvard University	1Harvey Mudd College	1International Space University	1Iowa Wesleyan College	1Johns Hopkins University	1Leeds University	1LeMoyne College	1Madigan University of Washington	1Missouri Southern State College	1Naval Postgraduate School	1New York University	1North Carolina State University	1Northwestern University	1Oregon State University	1Queen's University	1Rutgers University	1Saint John's University	1San Diego State University	1San Francisco State University	1Southeastern Massachusetts University	1State University of New York Maritime College	1Tennessee Technological University	1Texas A&M University	1The Citadel	1Troy State University	1Tulane University	1Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences	1University of Bath	1University of Bristol	1University of California - Berkeley	1University of California - Davis	1University of California - Santa Barbara	1University of Colorado	1University of Connecticut	1University of Edinburgh	1University of Florida	1University of Illinois	1University of Massachusetts 	1University of Missouri-Rolla	1University of North Dakota	1University of Pennsylvania	1University of Rochester	1University of Southern California	1University of Texas Medical Branch	1U.S. Army War College	1U.S. Coast Guard Academy	1U.S. Naval Postgraduate School	1U.S. Naval War College	1Vanderbilt University	1Virginia Polytechnic Institute	1Wake Forest University	1Washington University	1Western Kentucky University	1Wright State University	1University of Chicago	1

Unlikely. The astronaut and NASA employee selection process is very long and stressful, but if you know your stuff, and are capable of advanced problem solving you should do well. Even if you went to a Liberal Arts College in mid state Kansas you should be OK, counting on of course your knowledge and skills in the job you are applying for. Now it does help to have a selective Engineering school on your resume but if you know your stuff, they'll know it. As long as you meet the requirements you will put through the same tests as the people with spectacular schools such as MIT and Stanford on their list.
